advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A selection for the Initiator... at Sinclair price</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRO7 COVERPAGE (SEPT. 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Micro7 was a french computing magazine in the 80's. In september 84, its first page was featuring the EXl-100.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOGS (1993)</strong></font><br><blockquote>WP-3 model</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.K. AD (OCT. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The letters you send speak volumes for your company's image. Scrappy typing, untidy layouts and poor spelling announce that you're less than professional outfit.<br> Whereas beautifully presented correspondence shows quite clearly that you're a company to be reckoned with.<br> Now Amstrad's new wordprocessor with daisywhell printer and spellcheck facility means that any company can produce superb quality letters, reports and documents.<br> With the minimum of effort and for a minimal outlay.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PREVIOUS SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Before manufacturing the MPC, Columbia tried to sell a massive multi-user, Z80 based system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HARD WORKING MAN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture shows a man smiling while looking at his personal account...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV FEB. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Kaypro, it runs" ! <br><br> "Kaypro, the computer which can be carried away" <br><br> "Elected Transportable Computer of the year"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SUPERBRAIN II ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>SuperBrain II's internal circuitry has been completely redesigned. There were four models availables, from 350 KB to 10 MB of storage capacity.<br><br> The new version offered a faster enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes ans better graphics capabilities. <br><br> Prices started at $2,495</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br> ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz - http://www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The CP-200 and CP-200S computers were Brazilian clones of the Sinclair ZX81.
However, to compete with the original model and local ZX81 clones, CP-200 models featured several enhancements.
The larger case housed the power supply unit and a slightly better rubber keyboard. Basic versions had 16 KB of RAM as well as a joystick interface cabled in parallel with some keyboard keys. The BASIC interpreter also had some improvements and additional commands.
The CP-200 also had one very unique characteristic being that the video display was inverted (white on black instead of black on white for the ZX-81). Any key pressed on the keyboard generated a "beep" sound coming from the buzzer (his only function).
The bus connector wasn't strictly Sinclair compatible (pinout was different), but an adaptor card (?) allowed all Sinclair and third companies peripherals to be used with both CP-200 models.
The CP-200s was the same computer but with a redesigned motherboard in a new smaller (hence the "s"?) plastic case. The goal was maybe to reduce the production costs.
____________
Contributed to this article : Paolo F. Pugno, Oscar Arthur Koepke
computer.name: CP-200
computer.ports: RF TV video output (channel 3 VHF), tape recorder In/Out, Bus connector, joystick

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CP-200 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same model with a different Prologica label</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Although better than the original ZX-81's, the small and spongy keys doesn't allow fast typing.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT & RIGHT SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>The expansion connector (not Sinclair compatible) is located on the left side, covered by a plastic lid.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ULA custom chip of the ZX81 is here remplaced by about 25 standard logic chips. <br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Expansion connector, not Sinclair compatible<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> 16 KB ROM chips, hold the BASIC interpreter<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 16 KB RAM chips - 8 x NS MM5290, 4116 equivalent<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Tape interface connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> RF UHF modulator<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Video connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> +5V, +12V, -12V power regulators<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Buzzer<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Zilog Z80A processor. </blockquote>
